responses.content_en: Contact eczema, also known as contact dermatitis, presents with symptoms such as redness, itching, swelling, and sometimes blistering of the skin upon contact with certain substances. Treatment involves identifying and avoiding triggers, using emollients to moisturize the skin, and applying topical corticosteroids to reduce inflammation. Corticosteroids should be used as directed by a healthcare professional, typically for a short duration and in a thin layer over affected areas. If symptoms persist or worsen despite treatment, or if there are signs of infection, it's advisable to consult a dermatologist for further evaluation and management.

Trichostasis spinulosa is a skin condition characterized by the presence of small, dark spots or bumps on the skin, particularly on the face, chest, or upper arms. These spots are actually hair follicles that contain trapped hairs, giving them a spiky appearance. Symptoms may include visible dark spots, rough texture, and occasionally, mild itching. Treatment typically involves gentle exfoliation with a mild cleanser and the use of topical retinoids or alpha hydroxy acids to promote skin cell turnover and prevent hair follicle blockage. Examples of topical treatments include adapalene gel or glycolic acid cream, which should be applied once daily for several weeks to see improvement. If symptoms persist or worsen, it's important to consult with a dermatologist for further evaluation and management.

Compound nevus, also known as a mole, typically appears as a small, round, brown spot on the skin. Symptoms include asymmetrical shape, irregular borders, and varying colors. If a mole changes in size, shape, or color, or if it becomes itchy, painful, or bleeds, it may require medical attention. While most moles are harmless, monitoring changes is crucial. Over-the-counter pain relievers like acetaminophen or ibuprofen can alleviate discomfort. However, for diagnosis and treatment, consult a dermatologist, especially if you notice changes in your mole.

superficial telangiectasias or spider veins, small blood vessels that sit near the skin’s surface and widen and create visible patterns of lines. People often refer to them as spider veins. They can occur anywhere on the body or face. For most people, telangiectasias neither cause any damage to overall health nor require treatment. However, they can sometimes indicate a more severe medical condition and may warrant closer inspection. There is no cure for telangiectasia, but it is treatable. Laser therapy is minimally invasive and is typically the most straightforward treatment for telangiectasia and broken capillaries. Laser ablation can seal the widened blood vessels. This procedure does not cause much pain, and the recovery time is short. Sclerotherapy is also an effective option where a solution is injected into the veins causing inflammation and hence shrinkage of the veins.

It's important to have lesions examined by a dermatologist for proper diagnosis and treatment. They can provide personalized recommendations based on your individual needs and medical history. If you're experiencing symptoms such as skin lesions, it's best to seek medical advice promptly. A dermatologist can perform a thorough examination and recommend appropriate treatment options, which may include topical medications, oral medications, or procedures depending on the nature of the lesions. Please schedule an appointment with a dermatologist for further evaluation and management.

Discoid eczema. Discoid eczema is a common type of eczema/dermatitis defined by scattered, well-defined, coin-shaped, and coin-sized plaques of eczema. The eruption can be precipitated by a localized injury such as a scratch, insect bite or thermal burn, impetigo or wound infection, contact dermatitis, or dry skin. Discoid eczema can also occur in association with atopic eczema. Scrapings are commonly taken for mycology, as discoid eczema can look very similar to tinea corporis (ringworm infection). As discoid eczema is associated with loss of skin barrier function, it is important to protect the skin from injury. Apply emollients frequently and avoid irritants. Use topical steroid cream twice daily for 2-4 weeks and oral antihistamines if needed. If resistant to treatment, consult your dermatologist to exclude ringworm or take a skin biopsy to exclude superficial basal cell carcinoma.

If you're experiencing symptoms such as skin lesions, it's best to seek medical advice promptly. A dermatologist can perform a thorough examination and recommend appropriate treatment options, which may include topical medications, oral medications, or procedures depending on the nature of the lesions. Please schedule an appointment with a dermatologist for further evaluation and management.

Longitudinal melanonychia presents as dark lines or streaks running along the length of the nail. It can be caused by various factors, including trauma, medication, or underlying medical conditions. If you notice longitudinal melanonychia, it's important to consult a dermatologist for proper evaluation, as it can sometimes be a sign of melanoma. Treatment typically involves addressing the underlying cause. However, if the melanonychia is benign and not associated with melanoma, treatment may not be necessary. In cases where treatment is warranted, it may involve surgical removal of the affected nail or topical medications prescribed by a dermatologist. Always follow your dermatologist's instructions regarding medication usage, duration, and any necessary follow-up appointments.

Excessive sweating of the hands, also known as palmar hyperhidrosis, can be distressing but is often manageable. Common symptoms include constantly moist or sweaty palms. For mild cases, over-the-counter antiperspirants containing aluminum chloride can be applied to the hands at night. Prescription-strength antiperspirants may be necessary for more severe cases. Oral medications like anticholinergics may help reduce sweating, but they come with potential side effects and should be used under medical supervision. In severe cases where other treatments fail, procedures like iontophoresis (using a device to deliver a mild electric current to the skin) or botulinum toxin injections can be considered. For personalized advice and treatment options, it's advisable to consult a dermatologist or healthcare provider.

Athlete's foot, also known as tinea pedis, is a fungal infection that typically affects the skin between the toes but can spread to other parts of the foot. Symptoms may include itching, burning, stinging, and cracking of the skin. In some cases, blisters or ulcers may also develop. To treat athlete's foot, over-the-counter antifungal creams or sprays containing ingredients such as clotrimazole, miconazole, or terbinafine can be applied to the affected area twice daily for at least 2 to 4 weeks, or as directed by a healthcare professional. It's important to keep the affected area clean and dry, wear clean socks made of breathable materials, and avoid walking barefoot in public places such as gym showers or locker rooms to prevent spreading the infection. If the symptoms persist or worsen despite treatment, or if you have diabetes or a weakened immune system, it's recommended to consult with a healthcare provider or dermatologist for further evaluation and management.

Inflammation of the nail fold, also known as paronychia, can cause symptoms such as redness, swelling, pain, and tenderness around the nail. For mild cases, soaking the affected finger or toe in warm water several times a day and keeping the area clean and dry may help. Over-the-counter pain relievers like ibuprofen or acetaminophen can help manage pain and inflammation. If the paronychia is severe or doesn't improve with home care, it's important to see a doctor, who may prescribe antibiotics such as dicloxacillin or cephalexin if there's evidence of bacterial infection. These antibiotics are typically taken for 7 to 14 days, as directed by your healthcare provider. If there's an abscess present, your doctor may need to drain it. Always follow your doctor's advice and finish the prescribed course of antibiotics even if symptoms improve, to ensure the infection is fully treated. If you have diabetes, a weakened immune system, or other underlying health conditions, it's especially important to seek medical attention promptly.

Common symptoms of tick bites include redness, swelling, itching, and in some cases, a bull's-eye rash. If you've been bitten by a tick and are experiencing symptoms, it's important to remove the tick carefully with tweezers, clean the area with soap and water, and apply an antiseptic cream. You should also monitor the area for any signs of infection, such as increasing redness, warmth, or pus. In certain cases, a doctor may prescribe antibiotics to prevent Lyme disease if the tick was infected. The prescribed antibiotics should be taken as directed by the doctor, typically for a duration of 10 to 21 days, depending on the severity of the bite and the presence of any symptoms. If you develop symptoms such as fever, headache, fatigue, muscle aches, or joint pain after a tick bite, you should seek medical attention promptly, as these could be signs of Lyme disease or another tick-borne illness. A dermatologist or infectious disease specialist can provide further evaluation and treatment if needed.

Dry thickened skin (callus) around the rim of the heel is the very first step towards cracking. Increased pressure on the fat pad under the heel causes it to expand sideways, leading to splitting or cracking of the callus. Some factors that contribute to cracking or splitting include excessive weight or obesity, Prolonged standing, especially on hard floors, and Open-back shoes and sandals, as they provide no support to hold the fat pad under the foot. You can try rubbing the heels with a moisturising cream on a regular basis to keep the skin supple and hydrated. Special heel balms are available that contain descaling (keratolytic) or water-retaining (humectant) agents, such as: Urea, Salicylic acid, Alpha-hydroxy acids, Saccharide isomerate. Feet should be inspected daily and on the first sign of any cracking, a moisturising routine 2–3 times a day may be all that is needed to heal the heel. A pumice stone can be rubbed gently against the callus to take away some of the thick hard skin before applying moisturiser.

Molluscum contagiosum presents as small, flesh-colored or pearly bumps with a dimpled center. It is a viral infection and it is contagious, so avoid touching it and avoid intimate contact to prevent the spread to others. If its present over genitalia get tested to rule out other STDs..These lesions are usually painless but may itch or become inflamed. To treat molluscum contagiosum, over-the-counter options like imiquimod cream or prescription treatments such as cryotherapy or curettage can be effective. If symptoms persist or worsen, consulting a dermatologist is advisable. Topical treatments typically require daily application for several weeks, while procedures like cryotherapy may only need one session.

These spots are actually hair follicles that contain trapped hairs, giving them a spiky appearance. Symptoms may include visible dark spots, rough texture, and occasionally, mild itching. Treatment typically involves gentle exfoliation with a mild cleanser and the use of topical retinoids or alpha hydroxy acids to promote skin cell turnover and prevent hair follicle blockage. Symptoms of lip biting may include redness, swelling, pain, and occasionally bleeding. For mild cases, applying a topical hydrocortisone cream can help reduce inflammation and discomfort. Ibuprofen or acetaminophen can be taken for pain relief as needed. Avoid biting the lips to allow them to heal properly. If symptoms persist or worsen, it's advisable to consult a dermatologist or dentist for further evaluation and treatment.

These spots are actually hair follicles that contain trapped hairs, giving them a spiky appearance. Symptoms may include visible dark spots, rough texture, and occasionally, mild itching. If symptoms persist or worsen, it's important to consult with a dermatologist for further evaluation and management.

Angular cheilitis, characterized by redness, inflammation, and fissures at the corners of the mouth, may cause pain or discomfort, especially when opening the mouth or eating. Treatment often involves applying antifungal or antibacterial creams, such as clotrimazole or miconazole, to the affected area twice daily for 1-2 weeks. Additionally, keeping the affected area clean and dry and avoiding licking or biting the lips can help facilitate healing. If symptoms persist or worsen despite treatment, it's advisable to consult a dermatologist or healthcare professional for further evaluation and management.

Nodular melanoma where melanoma cells proliferate downwards through the skin presenting as a rapidly enlarging lump. It can arise de novo in normal-appearing skin or within an existing melanoma of another type. These cells may occasionally arise from an existing melanocytic naevus (about 3%) but commonly occur within another type of melanoma or in previously normal-appearing skin. What triggers the melanocytes to become malignant is unknown, but it is likely to be a series of changes to the DNA. It is essential to diagnose nodular melanoma accurately. Clinical diagnosis is aided by dermoscopy and skin biopsy (usually excision biopsy) at your dermatologist. Those with melanoma that is more than 1 mm thick may be advised to have a lymph node biopsy, imaging studies, and blood tests. The initial treatment of primary melanoma is to cut it out; the lesion should be completely excised with a 2-3 cm margin of normal tissue.

This is a blood collection. With age, the skin has thinned out so whenever there is mild trauma or if you scratch the area the blood vessels which are now lying superficially bleed. This gets aggravated if you are already on blood thinners. Apply moisturizer. Avoid scratching. I have added a cream to be applied twice daily till it heals.

Please schedule an appointment with a dermatologist for further evaluation and management.

Symptoms of corns may include thickened, hardened skin with a raised bump or core, pain or tenderness when pressure is applied, and discomfort while wearing shoes or walking. For treatment, over-the-counter corn pads with salicylic acid can help soften and remove the corn. Apply as directed on the packaging, usually once daily, and continue use until the corn resolves, typically within 2-4 weeks. If the corn persists or becomes painful, it's advisable to consult a podiatrist or dermatologist for further evaluation and treatment options tailored to your specific needs.

Irritated moles may present with redness, itching, tenderness, or bleeding. If a mole becomes irritated, it's crucial to have it evaluated by a dermatologist to rule out any concerning changes. Depending on the assessment, the dermatologist may recommend a topical corticosteroid cream, such as hydrocortisone, to reduce inflammation and relieve symptoms. Typically, the cream should be applied thinly to the affected area once or twice daily for up to two weeks or as directed by the dermatologist. However, self-treatment should only be initiated after consultation with a healthcare professional, and any changes in the mole's appearance, such as growth, irregular borders, or color changes, should prompt immediate medical attention.

Get your hemoglobin and vitamin B12 levels checked. Symptoms of lip dryness include dry, cracked, or chapped lips, sometimes accompanied by redness, flaking, or discomfort. For mild cases, over-the-counter remedies like lip balms containing ingredients like petrolatum, beeswax, or shea butter can provide relief. Apply lip balm liberally throughout the day as needed, especially before going outside in cold or windy weather, or before bed. For more severe cases of lip dryness that do not improve with over-the-counter treatments, or if you experience bleeding, blistering, or signs of infection, it's important to consult with a dermatologist or healthcare provider for further evaluation and treatment. Apply moisturizer. I am adding a cream for faster healing to be applied twice daily for 2 weeks. Avoid lip color, irritants, and tongue licking. Use white colored toothpaste.

ringworm infection, a very contagious infection so it's important to use the right antifungal medicine as long as you can (around 2 weeks) to ensure that the ringworm does not re-appear a few weeks after you stop treating it. After touching the area with ringworm, wash your hands before touching another area of your body. Ringworm thrives in warm, moist areas, so you want to keep the area clean and dry. Avoid wearing clothes, socks, and shoes that make you sweat. Shower after working out and avoid sharing towels and other personal items. To avoid re-infecting yourself with infected items, you should wash clothes, towels, and bedding that you use while you have ringworm. Be sure to wash everything in hot, soapy water. If you suspect your pet has ringworm, take the animal to your vet as some types of ringworms grow on pets. Apply topical antifungal cream (preferably azoles group like miconazole or clotrimazole) twice daily for 2-4 weeks and sometimes systemic antifungal is used in resistant cases.

It's important to keep the affected area clean and dry, wear clean socks made of breathable materials, and avoid walking barefoot in public places such as gym showers or locker rooms to prevent spreading the infection. If the symptoms persist or worsen despite treatment, or if you have diabetes or a weakened immune system, it's recommended to consult with a healthcare provider or dermatologist for further evaluation and management.

If you're experiencing symptoms such as skin lesions, it's best to seek medical advice promptly. A dermatologist can perform a thorough examination and recommend appropriate treatment options, which may include topical medications, oral medications, or procedures depending on the nature of the lesions. Please schedule an appointment with a dermatologist for further evaluation and management.

Solar lentigines, also known as sunspots or age spots, are flat, brown or black spots that develop on sun-exposed areas of the skin, such as the face, hands, shoulders, and arms. They are typically harmless but can be bothersome cosmetically. Treatment options include topical creams containing hydroquinone, retinoids, or azelaic acid, which can help to lighten the spots over time. These creams are usually applied once or twice daily for several weeks to months, as directed by a dermatologist. Additionally, procedures such as laser therapy, cryotherapy, or chemical peels may be recommended for more stubborn or extensive solar lentigines. Anyways, it's best to consult with a dermatologist for personalized evaluation and management.

Atrophic scars are characterized by depressions or indentations in the skin, often resulting from conditions like acne, chickenpox, or injuries. Symptoms may include visible depressions or pits in the skin, uneven skin texture, and changes in skin pigmentation. Treatment options may include topical retinoids, such as tretinoin or adapalene, applied once daily at night for several months to promote collagen production and skin cell turnover. In some cases, dermatologists may recommend procedures like microneedling, chemical peels, or laser therapy to improve the appearance of atrophic scars. It's essential to consult with a dermatologist for a proper diagnosis and personalized treatment plan based on your individual needs and skin type.

Contact eczema, also known as contact dermatitis, presents with symptoms such as redness, itching, swelling, and sometimes blistering of the skin upon contact with certain substances. Treatment involves identifying and avoiding triggers, using emollients to moisturize the skin, and applying topical corticosteroids to reduce inflammation. Corticosteroids should be used as directed by a healthcare professional, typically for a short duration and in a thin layer over affected areas. If symptoms persist or worsen despite treatment, or if there are signs of infection, it's advisable to consult a dermatologist for further evaluation and management.

Pyogenic granuloma is an acquired benign proliferation of capillary blood vessels of the skin. Factors associated with the development of a pyogenic granuloma may include trauma, hormonal influences, medications like oral retinoids and infection. Treating or removing triggering factors is important to minimise the risk of recurrence. Topical treatment of pyogenic granuloma Imiquimod cream 5%, Timolol gel 0.5% and other topical (or oral) beta-blockers, Intralesional steroid injection, or cryotherapy. Procedural treatment includes curettage and cautery, surgical excision, vascular and ablative lasers

Dermatitis herpetiformis is a chronic autoimmune skin condition characterized by itchy, blistering lesions, typically occurring on the elbows, knees, back, and buttocks. Symptoms may also include redness, burning, and stinging sensations. Treatment usually involves medications to control symptoms and manage the underlying autoimmune response. Dapsone is commonly prescribed to alleviate itching and prevent new lesions. The typical dosage is 50 to 200 milligrams daily, with adjustments made based on individual response and tolerance. Additionally, a gluten-free diet is often recommended to manage dermatitis herpetiformis, as it is closely associated with celiac disease. However, it's crucial to consult a dermatologist for proper diagnosis and treatment, as well as to monitor for potential side effects of medications like dapsone.

Eczema symptoms can include red, itchy, and inflamed skin patches. Treatments may include topical corticosteroids like hydrocortisone cream for mild cases. For moderate to severe eczema, dermatologist may prescribe stronger corticosteroids or calcineurin inhibitors like tacrolimus. These medications should be applied thinly to affected areas once or twice daily. Additionally, moisturizers are essential for managing eczema; apply them liberally and frequently to keep the skin hydrated. If your eczema persists or worsens despite treatment, consult a dermatologist for further evaluation and management.

Over-the-counter pain relievers like acetaminophen or ibuprofen can alleviate discomfort. However, for diagnosis and treatment, consult a dermatologist, especially if you notice changes in your mole.

dark circles. There is hollowness present giving a tired and old look. Yes there is role of genetics; apart from that, inadequate water intake, sleep deprivation, increase in screen time, and stress play a role. So take care of these things. Get your Hb and TSH levels checked. I have added an under eye gel to be applied at night for 3 months. Do apply sunscreen. For hollowness, you can opt for hyaluronic acid fillers which lasts roughly for 12- 18 months.

Symptoms of eczema due to working in water may include redness, itching, dryness, and inflammation of the skin. For treatment, a doctor may prescribe topical corticosteroids such as hydrocortisone cream to reduce inflammation. Apply a thin layer to affected areas twice daily for up to two weeks. Additionally, moisturize regularly with a fragrance-free emollient to keep the skin hydrated. If symptoms persist or worsen, consult a dermatologist for further evaluation and management.

Lip licker's dermatitis may present with symptoms such as redness, dryness, scaling, and cracking around the lips. Over-the-counter hydrocortisone cream can help reduce inflammation. Apply a thin layer twice daily for up to 7 days. Additionally, use a gentle lip balm containing ingredients like petrolatum or beeswax to keep the lips moisturized. If symptoms persist or worsen despite treatment, consult a dermatologist for further evaluation and management.

Anyways, it's best to consult with a dermatologist for personalized evaluation and management.

Over-the-counter pain relievers like acetaminophen or ibuprofen can alleviate discomfort. However, for diagnosis and treatment, consult a dermatologist, especially if you notice changes in your mole.

These symptoms can arise from various conditions, including allergic reactions, skin irritations, eczema, or infections. If the symptoms are mild and transient, over-the-counter remedies like hydrocortisone cream or calamine lotion can help alleviate itching and reduce inflammation. These medications should be applied to the affected area as directed on the packaging, usually 2-3 times daily for up to 7 days. Additionally, antihistamines such as diphenhydramine (Benadryl) or loratadine (Claritin) can help relieve itching caused by allergies. These medications should be taken orally according to the recommended dosage on the packaging or as advised by a healthcare professional. However, if the itching, scratching, or friction persists or worsens despite using over-the-counter treatments, it's crucial to consult a dermatologist or healthcare provider for further evaluation and personalized treatment. They can assess the underlying cause of the symptoms and prescribe appropriate medications, such as topical corticosteroids, antifungal creams, or antibiotics, as needed. Follow the prescribed treatment plan and attend follow-up appointments as advised by your healthcare provider to monitor progress and ensure optimal management of your condition.

Symptoms of friction-related skin irritation may include redness, inflammation, tenderness, and sometimes the development of blisters or sores. For mild cases, over-the-counter hydrocortisone cream can help reduce inflammation and discomfort. Apply a thin layer to the affected area twice daily for up to one week. Keep the area clean and dry, and avoid further friction or irritation. If symptoms persist or worsen, or if you develop signs of infection such as increased pain, swelling, or pus, it's important to consult a dermatologist or healthcare professional for further evaluation and treatment. They may prescribe stronger topical steroids or antibiotics if needed, and they can provide personalized recommendations based on your specific condition and medical history.

Symptoms of lip biting may include redness, swelling, pain, and occasionally bleeding. For mild cases, applying a topical hydrocortisone cream can help reduce inflammation and discomfort. Ibuprofen or acetaminophen can be taken for pain relief as needed. Avoid biting the lips to allow them to heal properly. If symptoms persist or worsen, it's advisable to consult a dermatologist or dentist for further evaluation and treatment.

Psoriasis symptoms include red patches of skin covered with silvery scales, itching, burning, or soreness, thickened, pitted or ridged nails, swollen and stiff joints. Treatment options vary depending on the severity and type of psoriasis. For mild cases, over-the-counter (OTC) moisturizers, topical corticosteroids, vitamin D analogs, or retinoids may be prescribed. For moderate to severe psoriasis, prescription-strength topical treatments, phototherapy, oral medications like methotrexate, cyclosporine, or biologics may be recommended. Duration and direction for usage vary based on the specific medication and the patient's response. It's crucial to consult a dermatologist or healthcare provider for proper diagnosis and personalized treatment plan.

Heat rash, also known as prickly heat or miliaria, typically presents as small, red bumps or blisters on the skin, often accompanied by itching or prickling sensations. To relieve symptoms, it's essential to keep the affected area cool and dry. Over-the-counter hydrocortisone cream can help reduce inflammation and itching. Apply a thin layer to the affected area once or twice daily for up to one week, following the instructions on the package. Additionally, calamine lotion can soothe the skin and provide relief from itching. Apply as needed to the affected area. If symptoms persist or worsen despite treatment, or if you experience signs of infection such as increased redness, warmth, swelling, or pus, consult a dermatologist or healthcare professional for further evaluation and management.

Symptoms of corns may include thickened, hardened skin with a raised bump or core, pain or tenderness when pressure is applied, and discomfort while wearing shoes or walking. For treatment, over-the-counter corn pads with salicylic acid can help soften and remove the corn. Apply as directed on the packaging, usually once daily, and continue use until the corn resolves, typically within 2-4 weeks. If the corn persists or becomes painful, it's advisable to consult a podiatrist or dermatologist for further evaluation and treatment options tailored to your specific needs.

Solar lentigines, also known as sunspots or age spots, are flat, brown or black spots that develop on sun-exposed areas of the skin, such as the face, hands, shoulders, and arms. They are typically harmless but can be bothersome cosmetically. Treatment options include topical creams containing hydroquinone, retinoids, or azelaic acid, which can help to lighten the spots over time. These creams are usually applied once or twice daily for several weeks to months, as directed by a dermatologist. Additionally, procedures such as laser therapy, cryotherapy, or chemical peels may be recommended for more stubborn or extensive solar lentigines. Anyways, it's best to consult with a dermatologist for personalized evaluation and management.

Seborrheic keratosis is a common benign (noncancerous) skin growth. Seborrheic keratoses are not pre-cancerous, but they can resemble other skin growths that are. Your healthcare provider can help diagnose your seborrheic keratosis and remove it for you if you’d like. If in doubt, your healthcare provider may look at the growth under a dermascope, a small, handheld lighted microscope. If your healthcare provider suspects any cancer, they will want to take a sample or remove the whole growth to examine in a lab. You should always have new skin growths clinically diagnosed to make sure they aren’t cancerous. Different kinds of skin growths can be hard to tell apart from each other. Some over-the-counter topical treatments have shown promise for reducing seborrheic keratoses like tazarotene cream 0.1% and Alpha Hydroxy Acid (AHA) products, including glycolic acid and salicylic acid peels. Cryotherapy, electrotherapy, shave excision, and laser treatment are also treatment options

Inflammation of the nail fold, also known as paronychia, can cause symptoms such as redness, swelling, pain, and tenderness around the nail. For mild cases, soaking the affected finger or toe in warm water several times a day and keeping the area clean and dry may help. Over-the-counter pain relievers like ibuprofen or acetaminophen can help manage pain and inflammation. If the paronychia is severe or doesn't improve with home care, it's important to see a doctor, who may prescribe antibiotics such as dicloxacillin or cephalexin if there's evidence of bacterial infection. These antibiotics are typically taken for 7 to 14 days, as directed by your healthcare provider. If there's an abscess present, your doctor may need to drain it. Always follow your doctor's advice and finish the prescribed course of antibiotics even if symptoms improve, to ensure the infection is fully treated. If you have diabetes, a weakened immune system, or other underlying health conditions, it's especially important to seek medical attention promptly.

For treatment, over-the-counter corn pads with salicylic acid can help soften and remove the corn. Apply as directed on the packaging, usually once daily, and continue use until the corn resolves, typically within 2-4 weeks. If the corn persists or becomes painful, it's advisable to consult a podiatrist or dermatologist for further evaluation and treatment options tailored to your specific needs.

It's important to have lesions examined by a dermatologist for proper diagnosis and treatment. They can provide personalized recommendations based on your individual needs and medical history. If you're experiencing symptoms such as skin lesions, it's best to seek medical advice promptly. A dermatologist can perform a thorough examination and recommend appropriate treatment options, which may include topical medications, oral medications, or procedures depending on the nature of the lesions. Please schedule an appointment with a dermatologist for further evaluation and management.

dark circles. There is hollowness present giving a tired and old look. Yes there is role of genetics; apart from that, inadequate water intake, sleep deprivation, increase in screen time, and stress play a role. So take care of these things. Inflammatory acne symptoms include red, swollen, and painful bumps on the skin. For mild cases, over-the-counter benzoyl peroxide or salicylic acid-based products can be used daily for several weeks. For moderate to severe cases, prescription medications like topical retinoids or oral antibiotics may be needed. These should be used as directed by a dermatologist, typically for several weeks to months. It's important to follow the prescribed regimen closely and consult a dermatologist if symptoms persist or worsen.

periorificial dermatitis which initially responds to steroids but ultimately gets aggravated by steroids, so taper off the steroids you are already using. Apply the steroid cream every morning for 10 days, then on alternate days for next 10 days, and then stop. Start with antibiotic cream at night. I have also added an antibiotic to be taken once daily for a month. Keep the area clean. Use sunscreen.

dermatitis artefacta where skin lesions are solely produced or inflicted by the patient's own actions. This usually occurs as a result or manifestation of a psychological problem. It could be a form of emotional release in situations of distress or part of an attention seeking behaviour. Psychiatric referral is recommended and you should continue to see your doctor on an ongoing basis for supervision or support, whether or not lesions are present as dermatitis artefacta tends to wax and wane with the circumstances of your life.

Nodular melanoma where melanoma cells proliferate downwards through the skin presenting as a rapidly enlarging lump. It can arise de novo in normal-appearing skin or within an existing melanoma of another type. These cells may occasionally arise from an existing melanocytic naevus (about 3%) but commonly occur within another type of melanoma or in previously normal-appearing skin. What triggers the melanocytes to become malignant is unknown, but it is likely to be a series of changes to the DNA. It is essential to diagnose nodular melanoma accurately. Clinical diagnosis is aided by dermoscopy and skin biopsy (usually excision biopsy) at your dermatologist. Those with melanoma that is more than 1 mm thick may be advised to have a lymph node biopsy, imaging studies, and blood tests. The initial treatment of primary melanoma is to cut it out; the lesion should be completely excised with a 2-3 cm margin of normal tissue.

Apply a thin layer to the affected area once or twice daily for up to one week, following the instructions on the package. If symptoms persist or worsen despite treatment, or if you experience signs of infection such as increased redness, warmth, swelling, or pus, consult a dermatologist or healthcare professional for further evaluation and management.

Symptoms of lip biting may include redness, swelling, pain, and occasionally bleeding. For mild cases, applying a topical hydrocortisone cream can help reduce inflammation and discomfort. Ibuprofen or acetaminophen can be taken for pain relief as needed. Avoid biting the lips to allow them to heal properly. Trichostasis spinulosa is a skin condition characterized by the presence of small, dark spots or bumps on the skin, particularly on the face, chest, or upper arms. These spots are actually hair follicles that contain trapped hairs, giving them a spiky appearance. Symptoms may include visible dark spots, rough texture, and occasionally, mild itching. Treatment typically involves gentle exfoliation with a mild cleanser and the use of topical retinoids or alpha hydroxy acids to promote skin cell turnover and prevent hair follicle blockage. Examples of topical treatments include adapalene gel or glycolic acid cream, which should be applied once daily for several weeks to see improvement. If symptoms persist or worsen, it's important to consult with a dermatologist for further evaluation and management.

Eclipse nevi are dark, pigmented moles that can be concerning due to their potential association with melanoma. Symptoms may include a dark or black mole that appears suddenly, often with irregular borders or changes in size or color. It's crucial to monitor these moles for any changes and seek prompt medical attention if any concerning signs develop. Treatment typically involves surgical removal of the nevus, followed by histological examination to rule out malignancy. If you notice any changes in your moles or have concerns about eclipse nevi, it's essential to consult a dermatologist for evaluation and appropriate management.

If you're experiencing symptoms such as skin lesions, it's best to seek medical advice promptly. Please schedule an appointment with a dermatologist for further evaluation and management.

Lip licker's dermatitis may present with symptoms such as redness, dryness, scaling, and cracking around the lips. Over-the-counter hydrocortisone cream can help reduce inflammation. Apply a thin layer twice daily for up to 7 days. Additionally, use a gentle lip balm containing ingredients like petrolatum or beeswax to keep the lips moisturized. If symptoms persist or worsen despite treatment, consult a dermatologist for further evaluation and management.

Athlete's foot, also known as tinea pedis, is a fungal infection that typically affects the skin between the toes but can spread to other parts of the foot. Symptoms may include itching, burning, stinging, and cracking of the skin. In some cases, blisters or ulcers may also develop. To treat athlete's foot, over-the-counter antifungal creams or sprays containing ingredients such as clotrimazole, miconazole, or terbinafine can be applied to the affected area twice daily for at least 2 to 4 weeks, or as directed by a healthcare professional. It's important to keep the affected area clean and dry, wear clean socks made of breathable materials, and avoid walking barefoot in public places such as gym showers or locker rooms to prevent spreading the infection. If the symptoms persist or worsen despite treatment, or if you have diabetes or a weakened immune system, it's recommended to consult with a healthcare provider or dermatologist for further evaluation and management.

Excessive sweating of the hands, also known as palmar hyperhidrosis, can be distressing but is often manageable. Common symptoms include constantly moist or sweaty palms. For mild cases, over-the-counter antiperspirants containing aluminum chloride can be applied to the hands at night. Prescription-strength antiperspirants may be necessary for more severe cases. Oral medications like anticholinergics may help reduce sweating, but they come with potential side effects and should be used under medical supervision. In severe cases where other treatments fail, procedures like iontophoresis (using a device to deliver a mild electric current to the skin) or botulinum toxin injections can be considered. For personalized advice and treatment options, it's advisable to consult a dermatologist or healthcare provider.

Common symptoms of tick bites include redness, swelling, itching, and in some cases, a bull's-eye rash. If you've been bitten by a tick and are experiencing symptoms, it's important to remove the tick carefully with tweezers, clean the area with soap and water, and apply an antiseptic cream. You should also monitor the area for any signs of infection, such as increasing redness, warmth, or pus. In certain cases, a doctor may prescribe antibiotics to prevent Lyme disease if the tick was infected. The prescribed antibiotics should be taken as directed by the doctor, typically for a duration of 10 to 21 days, depending on the severity of the bite and the presence of any symptoms. If you develop symptoms such as fever, headache, fatigue, muscle aches, or joint pain after a tick bite, you should seek medical attention promptly, as these could be signs of Lyme disease or another tick-borne illness. A dermatologist or infectious disease specialist can provide further evaluation and treatment if needed.
